newsitem.title: UK: London gold weakens to fresh 4-1/4 year low.
newsitem.headline: London gold weakens to fresh 4-1/4 year low.

text.p: The gold market weakened to a fresh lowest price since March 1993 on Wednesday under pressure from speculative selling.
It was fixed at $331.45 per ounce, down from $333.70 on Tuesday marking its lowest fixing since March 24, 1993.
Dealers and analysts forecast lower prices to come for the yellow metal which has been under pressure for most of this year.
"The present price comes from a new level of short positions established by the investment funds (this week)," one analyst at a major European bullion bank said.
It was the funds' positioning to take advantage of prices falling further that had broken the gold price out of its previous price range between $335-$340, the analyst said.
That in turn had induced gold producers especially in high cost areas like Australia to step up their selling campaigns to avoid even lower prices.
"The Australians are concerned about a further interest rate cut at home and are trying to take advantage of the domestic currency moving in their favour," the analyst added.
Meanhwhile physical demand has slumped despite the apparent attractiveness of cheap prices.
Some observers even said that buyers in the recent past were now looking to sell back their gold holdings.
The lack of physical buying could be connected to the markets in Hong Kong being closed so far this week for the territory's hand over to Chinese rule.
"We are waiting to see if there is a reaction on the re-entry of Hong Kong," a dealer said. Hong Kong is one of the key gold entrepot points for China.
Some dealers said a European central bank -- Belgium was the favourite - had been selling gold from its reserves which also explained the staggering price but others were less sure.
"It is more likely to be a bullion bank selling possibly as a result of additional lending (to the market) by a central bank," a market analyst said.
Meanwhile the other precious metals largely ignored gold's problems. Silver was just a couple of cents lower at $4.64/$4.66 but platinum and palladium were both down for their own reasons.
Platinum was indicated at $425.00/$429.00 down $15.50 and palladium was $3.00 easier at $189.00/$192.00
Both were weaker on news major supplier Russia would begin its delayed 1997 exporting campaign on July 10.
